page.title: 17Flooding
page.content: Situated in a valley and with a network of rivers running through it, Chew Magna has always been susceptible to flooding. It was in 1968 that the Great Flood came. On 10th July heavy rain in the afternoon was followed by violent and prolonged thunderstorms, which lasted for more than 6 hours. The ground was unable to absorb the volume of water and roads soon became rivers, sweeping debris along with them. Many low-lying houses were flooded and residents were rescued from first-floor windows. The Primary School was just one of the buildings flooded. Fortunately and miraculously nobody drowned. An improved sluice gate system has prevented subsequent serious flooding in the village although the possibility is always there.A flood warden co-ordinator and flood wardens are on stand-by.
